Chitosan synergistically enhanced by successive Fe3O4 and silver nanoparticles as a novel green catalyst in one-pot, three-component synthesis of tetrahydrobenzo[α]xanthene-11-ones Reza Mohammadi Esmaiel Eidi Monireh Ghavami Mohammad Zaman Kassaee ⁎ Department of Chemistry, Tarbiat Modares University, P.O. Box 14155-4838, Tehran, Iran Department of Chemistry, Tarbiat Modares University P.O. Box 14155-4838 Tehran Iran ⁎ Corresponding author. Tel.: +98 912 1000392; fax: +98 21 88006544. Graphical abstract Chitosan (CS) is modified with Fe3O4 nanoparticles composite through in situ co-precipitation of Fe3+ and Fe2+ ions via NH4OH in an aqueous solution, resulting in magnetic Fe3O4/CS NPs. Adsorption of Ag+ ions on the surface of the latter, followed by green reduction of Ag+ via ascorbic acid, renders Fe3O4/CS-Ag NPs which shows an excellent catalytic activity toward one-pot, three-component synthesis of 12-aryl-8,9,10,12-tetrahydrobenzo[α]xanthene-11-one derivatives. The composition of the nanocatalyst is analyzed by FT-IR, XRD, TGA, VSM, ICP, SEM and TEM. Hence unique heterogeneous Fe3O4/CS-Ag NPs acts as an excellent green catalyst giving high yield product with good recyclability and without significant loss of the activity. Keywords Silver NPs Chitosan Fe3O4 NPs Synergistic 12-Aryl-8,9,10,12-tetrahydrobenzo[α]xanthene-11-ones 1 Introduction Fabrication of nanoparticles with desired properties through their surface modifications have attracted growing attention in recent years [1,2]. As such an ever increasing interest is generated in the synthesis, characterization and surface modification of magnetic nanoparticles because of their potential applications in biotechnology, biomedicine, environmental, material science and catalysis [3–5]. Intriguing feature of these nanoparticles is the possibility to tune their properties through a molecular-level design by varying the size of the core and by surface modification with suitable functionalities. Polysaccharides are among the various stabilizing agents used to prevent nanoparticles from aggregating, and represent an attractive choice for preparation of functional materials [6,7]. In particular, an increasing attention has recently been focused on the synthesis of CS coated Fe3O4 NPs [8–10]. As an ideal support material, CS has its special set of properties including availability, safety, non-toxicity, biocompatibility, biodegradability, low immunogenicity, and antibacterial properties [11–13]. Owing to these fascinating properties, CS has found a wide application in a variety of areas such as industry, biomedicine, pharmaceuticals, metal chelating, food processing, etc. [14–16]. On the other hand metallic nanoparticles have been a topic of intense research mainly because of their unique physical and chemical properties compared with their bulk counterparts. They have many excellent properties such as unique optical, electronic, magnetic, chemical, and thermal behaviors as well as the large surface to volume ratio [17–19]. The literature is rich with examples of metallic nanoparticles exhibiting excellent catalytic activities. Many metallic nanoparticles can be employed as heterogeneous catalyst and most likely be recycled [20,21]. Ag NPs are of particular interest due to their role as substrates in the studies of catalysis, surface enhancement, Raman spectroscopy, and in the biomedical fields [22–25]. Because of their vast applications, many techniques for synthesizing Ag NPs have been reported including: microemulsion, chemical, electrochemical, and photochemical reductions; as well as gamma-ray, UV, ultrasonic and microwave methods [26–32]. Here we report synthesis of Fe3O4/CS-Ag NPs, which is applied as a green, effective, clean, and recoverable magnetic nanocatalyst for the synthesis of important 12-aryl-8,9,10,12-tetrahydrobenzo[α]xanthene-11-one derivatives. The latter are of importance for having various biological and pharmaceutical activities such as antibacterial, anti-inflammatory, antiviral, antimalaria, and antitumor properties [33–35]. Some xanthene based compounds have found both applications as antagonists for inhibiting the activity of zoxalamine, and in photodynamic therapy [36]. In addition, they can be used as dyes, in laser technology, and pH sensitive fluorescent materials for visualization of biomolecular assemblies [37–39]. These make syntheses of xanthene derivatives of great importance. In the past decade, various methods have been developed for the synthesis of tetrahydrobenzo(α)xanthenes. Generally they are synthesized by the three-component condensation of a cyclic 1,3-diketones with an aldehyde and 2-naphthol. It entails the use of PTSA in ionic liquid, sulfonic acid functionalized imidazolium salts, tetrabutyl ammonium fluoride, strontium triflate, methanesulfonic acid, glucose sulfonic acid along with proline triflate, etc. [40–50]. Here we have made an effort toward development of a new synthetic protocol involving Fe3O4/CS-Ag NPs in one-pot, tree-component reactions of benzaldehydes, 2-naphtol and 1,3-cyclohexadiones in water. Again, The Fe3O4/CS-Ag NPs catalyst is produced from environmentally green compounds. It's most basic part is CS, which as a biopolymer has its special set of properties including safety, non-toxicity, biocompatibility, biodegradability, low immunogenicity, and antibacterial properties. Catalytic activity of CS is synergistically enhanced by the green silver nanoparticles which have shown promising antibacterial properties [51,52]. Furthermore, our catalyst contains magnetic NPs of an iron oxide nature that is at the forefront of the current research, owing to its non-toxicity, biocompatibility, biodegradability, etc. [53,54]. Finally, Fe3O4/CS-Ag NPs can easily and efficiently be removed away from the product and none of it parts contaminates the environment. 2 Experimental 2.1 Preparation of chitosan-coated magnetic nanoparticles: Fe3O4/CS NPs Fe3O4 nanoparticles are prepared by chemical co-precipitation of Fe3+ and Fe2+ ions with molar ratio of 2:1, in the presence of CS, followed by the hydrothermal treatment. Specifically, FeCl3·6H2O (1.76g, 0.0065mol) and FeCl2·4H2O (0.65g, 0.0033mol) are added to 1.5g of CS (average molecular weight: 100,000–300,000) dissolved in 100mL of 0.05M acetic acid solution. The resulting solution is mechanically stirred for 6h at 80°C, under N2 atmosphere. Then 6mL of 25% NH4OH is injected drop wise into the reaction mixture with constant stirring. After 30min, the mixture is cooled to room temperature and magnetic nanoparticles coated over chitosan are separated by an external magnet, washed first with distilled water, then ethanol, and finally dried under vacuum at room temperature. 2.2 Synthesis of silver nanoparticles coated magnetic chitosan: Fe3O4/CS-Ag NPs 500mg of Fe3O4/CS NPs is dispersed in water (30mL) in an ultrasonic bath for 30min, then an aqueous solution of AgNO3 (300mg in 5mL) is added drop-wise over a period of 10min, at room temperature. The mixture is mechanically stirred for 4h. Subsequently, 2mL of 0.1M ascorbic acid is gradually added to the mixed solution of chitosan magnetic nanoparticles and AgNO3, then continued stirring for 3h. The solution changes from colorless to gray green, indicating the completion of the reaction. Finally, Fe3O4/CS-Ag NPs is separated by an external magnet, washed several times with water and dried under vacuum at room temperature (Scheme 1 ). 2.3 General procedure for synthesis of 12-aryl-8,9,10,12-tetrahydrobenzo[α]xanthene-11-ones Fe3O4/CS-Ag NPs (15mg) is added to a mixture of a benzaldehyde (1mmol), 2-naphtol (1mmol), and a 1,3-cyclohexadione (1mmol) in water (5mL), and the reaction mixture is stirred at 80°C (Scheme 2 ). The progress of the reaction is monitored by TLC. After the reaction is completed, the catalyst is separated by an external magnet and reused as such for the next experiment. The crude product is extracted from the aqueous phase by EtOAc, and then the organic layer is washed with saturated brine and dried over anhydrous MgSO4. Finally, the combined organic layers are evaporated under reduced pressure and the resulting crude product is recrystallized from hot ethanol. The heterogeneous catalyst is fully characterized by FT-IR (Fig. 1 ), XRD (Fig. 2 ), TGA (Fig. 3 ), VSM (Fig. 4 ), SEM (Fig. 5 ), TEM (Fig. 6 ) and ICP-OES. 3.1 FT-IR analysis Spectral scrutiny of CS, Fe3O4/CS NPs, and Fe3O4/CS-Ag NPs are instructive (Fig. 1). The FT-IR spectrum of CS shows a broad band at 3427cm−1 which corresponds to the stretching vibrations of NH and OH groups. Peaks appearing at 2922 and 2856cm−1 are characteristic of CH stretching vibrations. The band at 1649cm−1 is assigned to NH bending vibration and that of 1424cm−1 to CO stretching of primary alcoholic groups in CS. The bio-sorption bands around 1093 and 1027cm−1 display the stretching vibrations of the CO bonds. In Fe3O4/CS NPs, absorptions of CS appear along with a peak at 594cm−1 which corresponds to the stretching vibration of FeO groups. This indicates that magnetic Fe3O4 NPs is coated by CS. Possible bindings of silver with NH2 and OH group in Fe3O4/CS-Ag NPs have decreased the combined intensity of amine and hydroxyl peaks at 3426cm−1. Splitting of the bending peaks of amine and hydroxyl at 1604cm−1 and 1416cm−1 also indicate the bonding of Ag with OH and NH2 groups. Changes in the region 1350cm−1 and 1000cm−1 may be attributed to the perturbation in CN vibrations induced Ag complex with CS. 3.2 X-ray diffraction (XRD) analyses The XRD patterns help determine the crystal structures of green synthesized Fe3O4/CS NPs and Fe3O4/CS-Ag NPs. Sharp peaks confirm the good crystallinity of the prepared samples (Fig. 2). For Fe3O4/CS NPs the results are in agreement with standard patterns of inverse cubic spinel magnetite (Fe3O4) crystal structure, showing six diffraction peaks at 2θ about 35.3°, 41.6°, 50.7°, 63.1°, 67.7° and 74.5°marked by their indices (220), (311), (400), (422), (511), and (440), respectively. The small and weak broad bands in the range of 21–29° indicate the existence of CS. Diffraction patterns of the Fe3O4/CS-Ag NPs exhibit three additional peaks at 2θ about 44.7°, 52.0° and 76.6°; corresponding to (111), (200) and (220) planes of face centered cubic (fcc) silver crystal structure. In addition Fe3O4 NPs and CS are shown in the Fe3O4/CS-Ag NPs with a decreased intensity. No impurities in the XRD patterns suggest formation of pure Fe3O4 and Ag nanoparticles. 3.3 Thermogravimetric analysis (TGA) In order to probe thermal stability, TGA experiments are carried out by heating CS, Fe3O4/CS NPs, and Fe3O4/CS-Ag NPs in air up to 600°C (Fig. 3). Pure CS shows a 5–10% weight loss at 110°C, due to the evaporation of adsorbed moisture. Another sharp down fall appears at 320°C, which could be attributed to the degradation of chitosan chains. The weight losses of CS, Fe3O4/CS NPs, and Fe3O4/CS-Ag NPs at 600°C are 66%, 43%, and 25%, respectively. Hence, the incorporation of Fe3O4 in Fe3O4/CS is about 23% (57–34%), while the incorporation of Ag in Fe3O4/CS-Ag NPs is 18% (75–57%). 3.4 Magnetic properties The magnetic properties of the as-synthesized Fe3O4/CS NPs and Fe3O4/CS-Ag NPs are measured at room temperature. The negligible coercivity and remanence in the magnetization curves indicate that they are super paramagnetic (Fig. 4). The saturation magnetization (MS) value of Fe3O4/CS-Ag NPs is 21.96emug−1, that is lower than that for Fe3O4/CS NPs (25.08emug−1). It may be ascribed to the existence of Ag NPs on Fe3O4/CS NPs. Both particles show high permeability in magnetization which facilitates magnetic separation with a conventional magnet (Fig. 4). Also, the content of Fe3O4 NPs, and Ag, in the synthesized catalyst (Fe3O4/CS-Ag NPs) is measured by inductively coupled plasma optical emission spectroscopy (ICP-OES). The catalyst content of 27% for Fe3O4, and 21% for Ag appear consistent with TGA observations. 3.5 Scanning electron microscopy (SEM) and transmission electron microscopy (TEM) The size and structures of the Fe3O4/CS NPs and Fe3O4/CS-Ag NPs are estimated using SEM and TEM. SEM shows uniformly dispersed spherical particles, along with weak agglomerations (Fig. 5). Comparison between TEM images of the above mentioned nanoparticles, shows Ag NPs embedded on the magnetic CS, forming the desired composite structure (Fig. 6). Multi-component facile synthesis of 12-aryl-8,9,10,12-tetrahydrobenzo[α]xanthene-11-ones is carried out in the presence of catalytic amounts of Fe3O4/CS-Ag NPs, in aqueous media. To establish the feasibility of the strategy and optimize the conditions, reaction of benzaldehyde, 2-naphtol, and 5,5-dimethyl-1,3-cyclohexanedione is adopted as a simple model (Scheme 2, Table 1 ). In order to probe the catalyst role, the model reaction is implemented in the presence of CS, Fe3O4 NPs, Ag NPs, Fe3O4/CS NPs, CS-Ag NPs, or Fe3O4/CS-Ag NPs. In addition, as the reaction is highly related with the synergistic effect between Ag, Fe3O4, and CS, their ratio in the catalyst is varied in order to see how it affects the catalytic activity. As anticipated, in the absence of the catalyst no product is produced. The reaction is highly related with the synergistic effect between Ag and CS and about 25% of Ag and 50% of CS in catalyst is sufficient. Fe3O4/CS-Ag NPs demonstrates the highest catalytic activity. The use of just 15mg of Fe3O4/CS-Ag NPs is sufficient to push the reaction forward. A catalyst amount higher than 50mg does not improve the yield to an appreciable extent (Table 1, entries 1–13). The model reaction is examined in a solvent free condition, as well as in H2O, EtOH, toluene, MeCN, CH2Cl2, and MeOH (Table 1, entries 14–19). Among them, water appears to be the solvent of choice. A plausible provisional mechanism is presented for formation of 12-aryl-8,9,10,12-tetrahydrobenzo[α]xanthene-11-ones (4) over our catalyst (Fe3O4/CS-Ag NPs) (Scheme 3 ). Accordingly, activation of the carbonyl group of benzaldehyde (1) by the Ag NPs Lewis acid portion of Fe3O4/CS-Ag NPs, leads to 5 which is attacked by nucleophile 2-naphthol (2) that is already activated through deprotonation via the NH2 groups present on the CS portion of catalyst. This results in the formation of the adduct 6 which gives orthoquinone methide (7) upon dehydration. In turn, Fe3O4/CS-Ag NPs activates intermediate 7, as a Michael acceptor, which is attacked by nucleophile 8 that has already been activated through deprotonation of 1,3-cyclohexanediones (3) via the NH2 groups. The result of this condensation reaction is formation of 9 which cyclyzes to 10 and subsequently renders 12-aryl-8,9,10,12-tetrahydrobenzo[α]xanthene-11-ones (4) upon dehydration. To investigate the efficiency of our method, a series of differently substituted benzaldehydes are employed (Scheme 2). The results clearly demonstrate high tolerance for a wide range of differently substituted benzaldehydes (Table 2 ). In a typical procedure, after completion of the reaction, the magnetic catalyst is easily and efficiently removed away from the product by attaching an external magnet to the reaction vessel, followed by simple decantation of the solution (Fig. 7 ). To determine possible leaching of the Ag NPs, 100mg of Fe3O4/CS-Ag NPs is dispersed in water for 1h, them the catalyst is removed by an external magnet. The resulting solution is tested by atomic absorption spectroscopy which shows no trace of silver. In addition the filtrate is tested after a standard reaction and no silver is detected. The recovered catalyst is washed with EtOH and dried for 4h at room temperature to ready for a later run. The percentage of the recovery step in most cases is more than 96%, without altering the physicochemical properties (Fig. 8 ). Moreover, the recovered catalyst is recycled in subsequent runs without any significant loss of its activity. For instance, using the same model reaction, the average isolated yield for seven successive runs is 91%, which demonstrates the practical recyclability of the prepared catalyst (Fig. 8). 4 Conclusion Silver NPs are implanted on nontoxic, biocompatible magnetic chitosan (CS). The resulting Fe3O4/CS-Ag NPs acts as a “green” heterogeneous, highly efficient and recyclable novel catalyst for preparation of 12-aryl-8,9,10,12-tetrahydrobenzo[α]xanthene-11-ones through one-pot, tree-component reactions of a benzaldehyde, 2-naphtol, and a 1,3-dicarbonyl compound in water. Green solvent, high yields, short reaction time, operational simplicity, practicability, applicability to various substrates and product purity are among the advantages of this protocol. coredata.dc:description: Chitosan (CS) is modified with Fe3O4 nanoparticles composite through in situ co-precipitation of Fe3+ and Fe2+ ions via NH4OH in an aqueous solution, resulting in magnetic Fe3O4/CS NPs. Adsorption of Ag+ ions on the surface of the latter, followed by green reduction of Ag+ via ascorbic acid, renders Fe3O4/CS-Ag NPs which shows an excellent catalytic activity toward one-pot, three-component synthesis of 12-aryl-8,9,10,12-tetrahydrobenzo[α]xanthene-11-one derivatives. The composition of the nanocatalyst is analyzed by FT-IR, XRD, TGA, VSM, ICP, SEM and TEM. Hence unique heterogeneous Fe3O4/CS-Ag NPs acts as an excellent green catalyst giving high yield product with good recyclability and without significant loss of the activity.
coredata.dc:title: Chitosan synergistically enhanced by successive Fe3O4 and silver nanoparticles as a novel green catalyst in one-pot, three-component synthesis of tetrahydrobenzo[α]xanthene-11-ones
